newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazilian shantytown to be painted in bright colors.
newsitem.headline: Brazilian shantytown to be painted in bright colors.

text.p: Rocinha, Rio's biggest shantytown, will get a facelift thanks to the Rio 2004 Olympic campaign and a film-maker who want to paint the ramshackle houses in bright colours, officials said on Tuesday.
Rio 2004 is coordinating a project to train and pay 100 residents of the slum to paint and repair their houses to help improve Rio's image in its bid to host the 2004 Olympic Games.

"We consider it important to improve the living quality and the infrastructure of the favela (shantytown)," said Andrea Siqueira of Rio 2004. "The plan is to paint part of the favela in coming weeks and if it proves to be successful other favelas might be included in the programme."
Rio 2004 has yet to choose the colours, but film-maker Sergio Peo also has multicolored plans for Rocinha.
He wants to paint the town red, green and blue and any other colour in the rainbow to provide the setting for his new film "Rocinha Night and Day", which starts filming in January.
"It will be the language of pop with strong colours," Peo said. "We want to paint a stretch of houses along the road at the bottom of the favela."
His movie tells the story of a pirate radio station which mobilises the residents of the shantytown to paint their houses as a symbol of community spirit in defiance of public neglect.
